title: Marlborough Pie
instructions: Use whatever pastry recipe you’d like to create the single crust. Mix flour, salt, and sugar with cold cubes of butter by hand until crumbly, then add just enough ice-cold water to bind the dough.

Divide the dough into two balls. Wrap and freeze one for a rainy day, then use the other one for the Marlborough pie. Refrigerate the pie dough for an hour, to let the gluten settle and the dough hydrate evenly.

Melt the butter and leave to cool. Prepare the stewed apples by peeling and dicing them, transferring them to a pot, and adding just enough water to cover. Boil until soft and simmer for about 30 minutes with a few dashes of ground cinnamon. Strain and mash the apples.

Squeeze the lemon, remove any seeds, and add the juice to 3/4 cup of the stewed apples. Add the sherry, cream, sugar, and mix until well incorporated. Add the melted butter, blending well. Beat and fold in the eggs.

Preheat the oven to 400°F. Roll out the pie crust into a deep (roughly 1½ to 2 inches deep), 8-inch pie plate. Add the grated nutmeg to the custard and spoon everything into the pastry-lined pie plate.

Bake for 15 minutes at 400°F. Reduce the heat to 350°F and bake for another 45 minutes or until a tester comes out clean. Place a baking tray or a sheet of aluminum foil on the bottom rack to catch any spills.
Note: Consider blind baking the crust for a firmer bottom. Line the unfilled crust with foil, weigh it down with coins or dried beans, and bake at 375°F for 10 minutes or until lightly brown.
